MRH Middle School Principal Mike Dittrich was recently named an advisor to Civic Arts Company, a Missouri non-profit which addresses issues of social injustice to foster understanding and community development. Last year, CAC presented a free live performance of the Studs Terkel play "Race" at the MRH middle school theatre.

"Our goals and his are fully aligned," said CAC director Terry Weiss. "And he is helping us to make our product better. Following our visit he continued the relationship, using our survey results to both broaden and deepen our approach. All this is being done collaboratively. No other principal has ever done that before."

"Even more, Mike is a self-described data nerd who is also an environmental activist," says Weiss. "He is helping us improve our survey instrument and collect data electronically. We couldn’t ask for a better partner or advisor for Civic Arts Company."

Learn more about the important work they are doing by visiting http://civicartscompany.org/

A series of summer camps is offered throughout the United States by Barça academy to identify soccer talent. From those camps, the top 10% are selected to travel to Barcelona, Spain, to train with Barça coaches. MRH middle schooler Caleb Bircher made the cut! While there, Caleb experienced soccer training on the beaches of Spain, scoring seven out of twelve goals in four games on international soil against premier academy teams and experienced training with world-class coaches. When he wasn’t training or playing, he had the opportunity to explore the city. At the end of the training the top 1% of players from the Barcelona trainings is invited to participate in the Mediterranean International Cup. Caleb was honored to be in that top tier.

Drone Programming

Scholars in Mr. Noud’s Technology Literacy class are currently immersed in their Drone Unit. As part of this unit, students have been exploring safety procedures for operating drones and possible hazards for both operators and spectators. Working in cooperative learning groups, students created anchor charts to help their classmates remember important information surrounding safety practices, illustrations of a drone’s axes of movement (including yaw, pitch, and roll), and labeling of the parts and operations of a drone. They then worked together to create code that would instruct the drone to fly in a square pattern using pitch and roll controls in both clockwise and counterclockwise directions. By connecting to their Chromebook’s Bluetooth, they were then able to test the effectiveness of their coding and their understanding of safety procedures by actually flying the drone. As an extended challenge, obstacles were introduced, and students were asked to land their drones on another table.
